column1: Sentence
David Cornell Leestma (born May 6, 1949) is a former American astronaut and retired Captain in the United States Navy.
Born May 6, 1949, in Muskegon, Michigan.
Married to the former Patti K. Opp of Dallas, Texas, they have six children.
He enjoys golfing, tennis, aviation, and fishing.
His parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harold F. Leestma, reside in Palm Desert, California.
His wife's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Opp, reside in New Braunfels, Texas.
Associate Fellow, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA); Life Member, Association of Naval Aviation.
He was awarded the Presidential Rank of Meritorious Executive Award in 1998 and again in 2004.
Leestma graduated first in his class from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1971.
He completed flight training and received his aviator wings in October 1973.
Leestma made three overseas deployments to the Mediterranean/North Atlantic areas while flying aboard the USS John F. Kennedy.
In 1977, he was reassigned to Air Test and Evaluation Squadron Four (VX-4) at Naval Air Station Point Mugu, California.
He also served as fleet model manager for the F-14A tactical manual.
He has logged over 3,500 hours of flight time, including nearly 1,500 hours in the F-14A.
Leestma retired from the Navy as a Captain.
He was selected by NASA to become an astronaut in 1980.
Following his first flight, Leestma served as a capsule communicator (CAPCOM) for STS-51-C through STS-61-A.
From February 1990 to September 1991, when he started training for his third space mission, Leestma served as Deputy Director of Flight Crew Operations.
Following this flight, he served as Deputy Chief and Acting Chief of the Astronaut Office.
Leestma was selected as the Director, Flight Crew Operations Directorate, in November 1992.
As Director, FCOD, he had overall responsibility for the Astronaut Office and for Johnson Space Center (JSC) Aircraft Operations.
During his tenure as Director, 41 Shuttle flights and 7 Mir missions were successfully flown.
He was responsible for the selection of Astronaut Groups 15, 16 and 17.
While director, he oversaw the requirements, development modifications of the T-38A transition to the T-38N avionics upgrades.
In September 1998, Leestma was reassigned as the Deputy Director, Engineering, in charge of the management of Johnson Space Center Government Furnished Equipment (GFE) Projects.
A veteran of three space flights, Leestma has logged a total of 532.7 hours in space.
He was a mission specialist on STS-41-G (October 513, 1984), STS-28 (August 813, 1989), and STS-45 (March 24 to April 2, 1992).
STS-41-G Challenger, launched from Kennedy Space Center, Florida, on October 5, 1984.
It was the sixth flight of the orbiter Challenger and the thirteenth flight of the Space Shuttle system.
The seven-person crew also included two payload specialists: one from Canada, and one Navy oceanographer.
Dave Leestma and Kathryn Sullivan successfully conducted a 3 hour extravehicular activity (EVA) to demonstrate the feasibility of actual satellite refueling.
STS-28 Columbia, launched from Kennedy Space Center, Florida, on August 8, 1989.

column2: The mission carried Department of Defense payloads and a number of secondary payloads.

column1: STS-45 Atlantis, launched from the Kennedy Space Center, Florida on March 24, 1992.

column2: During the nine-day mission the crew operated the twelve experiments that constituted the ATLAS-1 (Atmospheric Laboratory for Applications and Science) cargo.

column1: STS-45 landed on April 2, 1992 on Runway 33 at the Kennedy Space Center, Florida, after completing 142 orbits of the Earth.
Source: NASA biography
